name: hmmsearch
title: HMMSEARCH
description: <text lang="en">Search a sequence database with a profile HMM</text> </description>

public_seq_DB.prompt: Choose one public protein sequence database

precond.python: not perso_seq_DB  or ( perso_seq_DB and public_seq_DB )

perso_seq_DB.prompt: OR paste a personal protein sequence database

precond.python: not public_seq_DB or ( perso_seq_DB and public_seq_DB )

precond.perl: not defined $Bit_cutoff and $model_specific ne '--cut_ga' and $model_specific ne '--cut_nc'
precond.python: Bit_cutoff is None and model_specific != '--cut_ga' and model_specific != '--cut_nc'

format.python: ( "" , " -E " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

E_value_cutoff.comment: <text lang="en">In the per-target output, report target profiles with an E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0, meaning that on average, about 10 false positives will be reported per query, so you can see the top of the 'noise' and decide for yourself if it's really noise.</text> </comment>

Bit_cutoff.comment: <text lang="en">Instead of thresholding per-profile output on E-value, instead report target profiles with a bit score of >= value.</text> </comment>

domE.prompt: E-value cutoff for the per-domain ranked hit list (--domE)

precond.perl: not defined $domT and $model_specific ne '--cut_ga' and $model_specific ne '--cut_nc'
precond.python: domT is None and model_specific != '--cut_ga' and model_specific != '--cut_nc'

format.python: ( "" , " --domE " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

domE.comment: <text lang="en">In the per-domain output, for target profiles that have already satisfied the perprofile reporting threshold, report individual domains with a conditional E-value of <= value. The default is 10.0. A 'conditional' E-value means the expected number of additional false positive domains in the smaller search space of those comparisons that already satisfied the per-profile reporting threshold (and thus must have at least one homologous domain already).</text> </comment>

domT.prompt: Bit score cutoff for the per-domain ranked hit list  (--domT)
domT.comment: <text lang="en">Instead of thresholding per-domain output on E-value, instead report domains with a bit score of >= value.</text> </comment>

incE.prompt: Include sequences lower than this E-value threshold in output alignment  (--incE)

format.python: ( "" , " --incE " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

incE.comment: <text lang="en">Use an E-value of <= value as the per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01, meaning that on average, about 1 false positive would be expected in every 100 searches with different query sequences.</text> </comment>

incdomE.prompt: Include domains lower than this E-value threshold in output alignment  (--incdomE)

precond.python: incdomT is not None and model_specific is None

format.python: ( "" , " --incdomE " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

incdomE.comment: <text lang="en">Use a conditional E-value of <= value as the per-domain inclusion threshold, in targets that have already satisfied the overall per-target inclusion threshold. The default is 0.01.</text> </comment>

incT.prompt: Include sequences upper than this score threshold in output alignment  (--incT)
incT.comment: <text lang="en">Instead of using E-values for setting the inclusion threshold, instead use a bit score of >= the value as the per-target inclusion threshold. It would be unusual to use bit score thresholds with hmmscan, because you don't expect a single score threshold to work for different profiles; different profiles have slightly different expected score distributions.</text> </comment>

incdomT.prompt: Include domans upper than this score threshold in output alignment  (--incdomT)
incdomT.comment: <text lang="en">Instead of using E-values, instead use a bit score of >= value as the per-domain inclusion threshold. As with --incT above, it would be unusual to use a single bit score threshold in hmmscan.</text> </comment>

precond.perl: not defined $Bit_cutoff and not $E_value_cutoff == 10.0 and not defined $incdomT and  $incdomE == 0.01
precond.python: not Bit_cutoff and E_value_cutoff == 10.0 and incdomT is None and incdomE == 0.01

format.python: ( "" , " " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

model_specific.comment: <text lang="en">Curated profile databases may define specific bit score thresholds for each profile, superseding any thresholding based on statistical significance alone. To use these options, the profile must contain the appropriate (GA, TC, and/or NC) optional score threshold annotation; this is picked up by hmmbuild from Stockholm format alignment files. Each thresholding option has two scores: the per-sequence threshold x1 value and the per-domain threshold x2 value. These act as if -T x1 --incT x1 --domT x2 --incdomT x2 has been applied specifically using each model's curated thresholds.</text> <text lang="en">cut ga: Use the GA (gathering) bit scores in the model to set per-sequence (GA1) and per-domain (GA2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. GA thresholds are generally considered to be the reliable curated thresholds defining family membership; for example, in Pfam, these thresholds define what gets included in Pfam Full alignments based on searches with Pfam Seed models.</text> <text lang="en">cut_nc: Use the NC (noise cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (NC1) and per-domain (NC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. NC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the highest-scoring known false positive.</text> <text lang="en">cut_tc: Use the NC (trusted cutoff) bit score thresholds in the model to set per-sequence (TC1) and per-domain (TC2) reporting and inclusion thresholds. TC thresholds are generally considered to be the score of the lowest-scoring known true positive that is above all known false positives.</text> </comment>

max.prompt: Turn all heuristic filters off (less speed, more power) (--max)
max.comment: <text lang="en">Turn off all filters, including the bias filter, and run full Forward/Backward postprocessing on every target. This increases sensitivity somewhat, at a large cost in speed.</text> </comment>

format.python: ( "" , " --F1 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

F1.comment: <text lang="en">Set the P-value threshold for the MSV filter step. The default is 0.02, meaning that roughly 2% of the highest scoring nonhomologous targets are expected to pass the filter.</text> </comment>

format.python: ( "" , " --F2 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

F2.comment: <text lang="en">Set the P-value threshold for the Viterbi filter step. The default is 0.001.</text> </comment>

format.python: ( "" , " --F3 " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

F3.comment: <text lang="en">Set the P-value threshold for the Forward filter step. The default is 1e-5.</text> </comment>

nobias.comment: <text lang="en">Turn off the bias filter. This increases sensitivity somewhat, but can come at a high cost in speed, especially if the query has biased residue composition (such as a repetitive sequence region, or if it is a membrane protein with large regions of hydrophobicity). Without the bias filter, too many sequences may pass the filter with biased queries, leading to slower than expected performance as the computationally intensive Forward/Backward algorithms shoulder an abnormally heavy load.</text> </comment>

nonull2.prompt: Turn off biased composition score corrections (--nonull2)
nonull2.comment: <text lang="en">Turn off the 'null2' score corrections for biased composition.</text> </comment>

E_value_calculation.comment: <text lang="en">Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-sequence E-value calculations, rather than the actual number of targets seen.</text> </comment>

domZ.prompt: Set Z score of significant sequences, for domain E-value calculation  (--domZ)
domZ.comment: <text lang="en">Assert that the total number of targets in your searches is the value, for the purposes of per-domain conditional E-value calculations, rather than the number of targets that passed the reporting thresholds.</text> </comment>

format.python: ( "" , " --seed " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

seed.comment: <text lang="en">Set the random number seed to value. Some steps in postprocessing require Monte Carlo simulation. The default is to use a fixed seed (42), so that results are exactly reproducible. Any other positive integer will give different (but also reproducible) results. A choice of 0 uses a 'randomly chosen' seed.</text> </comment>

textw.prompt: Set max width of ASCII text output lines (--textw)

format.python: ( "" , " --textw " + str(value) )[ value is not None and value !=vdef ]

textw.comment: <text lang="en">Set the main output's line length limit to value> characters per line. The default is 120.</text> </comment>

notextw.prompt: Unlimit ASCII text output line width (--notextw)
notextw.comment: <text lang="en">Unlimit the length of each line in the main output. The default is a limit of 120 characters per line, which helps in displaying the output cleanly on terminals and in editors, but can truncate target profile description lines.</text> </comment>

acc.prompt: Prefer accessions over names in output (--acc)
acc.comment: <text lang="en">Use accessions instead of names in the main output, where available for profiles and/or sequences</text> </comment>

noali.prompt: Don't output alignments, so output is smaller (--noali)
noali.comment: <text lang="en">Omit the alignment section from the main output. This can greatly reduce the output volume.</text> </comment>

alnfile_name.prompt: File name of the multiple alignment of all hits (-A)
alnfile_name.comment: <text lang="en">Save a multiple alignment of all significant hits (those satisfying inclusion thresholds) to the file.</text> </comment>

perseqfile_name.prompt: File name of parseable table of per-sequence hits (--tblout)
perseqfile_name.comment: <text lang="en">Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-target' output, with one data line per homologous target model found</text> </comment>

perdomfile_name.prompt: File name of parseable table of per-domain hits (--domtblout)
perdomfile_name.comment: <text lang="en">Save a simple tabular (space-delimited) file summarizing the 'per-domain' output, with one data line per homologous domain detected in a query sequence for each homologous model.</text> </comment>

output_perseqfile_name.prompt: Output parseable table of per-sequence hits

output_perdomfile_name.prompt: Output parseable table of per-domain hits

comment: <text lang="en">hmmsearch reads an HMM from hmmfile and searches seqfile for significantly similar sequence matches.</text> <text lang="en">hmmsearch may take minutes or even hours to run, depending on the size of the sequence database.</text> <text lang="en">The output consists of four sections: a ranked list of the best scoring sequences, a ranked list of the best scoring domains, alignments for all the best scoring domains, and a histogram of the scores. sequence score may be higher than a domain score for the same sequence if there is more than domain in the sequence; the sequence score takes into account all the domains. All sequences scoring above the -E and -T cutoffs are shown in the first list, then every domain found in this list is shown in the second list of domain hits. If desired, E-value and bit score thresholds may also be applied to the domain list using the --domE and --domT options.</text> </comment>
